results.notes:
Small to medium sized puffball (large for Lycoperdon) growing on debris and decayed logs in tropical forest. The outer ornamentation sloughs off upon handling and has a grainy/sandy texture and is reminiscent of a sea urchin shell under the handlens. Some individuals have a strikingly long sterile base. Spore mass becomes yellow with olive tones at maturity. Spores are verrucose with a short pedicel the larger of which are about 4 um, but a range of sizes present (2,3um) of many irregular or collapsed spores. Capitillial threads appear unbranched and whip-like, with a range of diameters (up to 10um), yellow to brown in h20 and with conspicuous walls and occasional septa.

—

Mirrored on iNaturalist as observation 150269433 on March 4, 2023.

results.notes:
Hardwood forest.
Gills forked near stipe. Also, some forks seen vert close to the cap margin. This is something I would expect to see in R. variata (rather that R. aeruginea). But the gills are not as closely-spaced as with R. variata.
Spore dimensions 6.5-8 × 5-6.5 fit R. aeruginea. Warts small, up to 0.5 microns with some connections.
Stipe base bright yellow.

Two similarly-sized slightly post-mature fruiting bodies fused at stipe base growing under old oaks in deciduous woods. One of these had the following dimensions:
Cap = 9 cm ‘footprint’; cap flesh 2 cm thick above the stipe, white & marshmallowy in texture, erratically staining reddish-brown, resolving blackish
Tubes = 1.4 cm long max
Stipe = curved, ~10.5 cm long, subclavate, 1-1.2 cm wide just above the base (widest point) and narrowing sharply below to a pointy root; flesh cortex black upon sectioning, reddening and staining reddish-brown in near the apex and in areas in the periphery and then turning blackish, just like the cap flesh
I have found this species/organism at this exact location several times in the past: obs 70541, obs 72347, obs 73850, and obs 244420.

results.notes:
Growing on old shagbark hickory husks strewn about in mossy area. Lots of whitetail deer scat in this spot.
Seems to agree morphologically with obs 367877, which was found about 13 months ago in same exact location/habitat. But, the spores of this present observation are very small, 5-5.5 × 3.5-4 (when compared with 367877). Another (presumed) Flammulaster was found in this same location in 2019 that had small spores, obs 417729.
Cheilocystidia abundant, cylindrical, often tapered to an acute apex, some with apex tapered abruptly to a long thin projection (mucrinate?).
No pleurocystidia found.
Stipe surface with bundles of caulocystidia, some similar to cheilocystidia but larger and occasionally appearing to be septate. Also on stipe are clavate to ovoid cells some of which appear to be septate (also caulocystidia?).
Variously shaped cells found on pileus (via smash mount of cap surface).
results.location_name: Property at 239 Golf Course Rd., Hunlock Twp., Pennsylvania, USA

results.notes: Mixed woods though largely oak in the immediate area. Cap was skin dry but the outer stipe skin stuck to my fingers upon touching. Even in person I was unable to ascertain whether there was an annulus or if the stipe was just very floccus. Scent was somewhat chemical or bleach-like, the taste was bitter reminiscent of aspirin. I did not observe the bruising/staining that can be seen in the bulb – it appeared to have been there before cutting.

results.notes:
A cluster of 5 fruiting bodies growing in grass on the edge of woods / road shoulder. They were in not great shape (mushy and buggy) due to being exposed to a lot of afternoon sun, and all were mature judging by the color of the gills. Three fbs were collected, of which the largest one was absolutely riddled with fly larvae and was discarded.
The nearby trees were pitch pines, white oaks and sweet gum saplings (the latter tree is very unusual for this habitat). I’ve been visiting this spot for many years, but have never seen these mushrooms there before. Agaricus is pretty rare in this ecological niche, and A. vinosobrunneofumidus is by far the most commonly encountered species there, and it’s obviously not that.
The attached images showing the details of morphology. The cottony ornamentation on the lower stipe, including yellow concentric rings near the base (universal veil?), lack of a basal bulb, and a small, fragile ring are the salient features of this species. The thin-fleshed caps were creamy with splashes of yellow and pinkish pigments (?) and some light fluffy scales of brighter yellow (the blackish areas are actually a spore drop from overlapping caps). The largest cap had a footprint of 6-6.5 cm. The odor was strong, pleasant, sweetish, with a chocolate note and perhaps some fragrant tobacco note, not all that dissimilar from vinosobrunneofumidus.
Upon returning home I immediately saved a fresh tissue sample in CTAB buffer, and it will be sequenced.
Here is Dr. Kerrigan’s comment on this critter:
“From the color and general aspect I would guess it is either a member of section Arvenses or else a closely related section. It reminds me most of what Murrill called A. floridanus (at least as I interpret it) and what M. A. Curtis called A. amygdalinus (an illegitimate name). We know it comes as far up the East Coast as Long Island”.
I found what looks like the original description of A. floridanus by Peck in Murril’s “Dark-Spored Agarics: III. Agaricus”, Mycologia 14(4): p. 207 (1922)1:
“Pileus hemispheric or campanulate, becoming nearly plane, solitary or subcespitose, 9-I5 cm. broad; surface rimosely areolate or slightly strigose, becoming glabrous, whitish with a yellow or yellowish center; lamellae at first white, then pink, and finally dark brown or blackish; spores globose or broadly ellipsoid, 5-6 × 4-5 Î¼; stipe easily separable from the pileus, equal or slightly thickened at the base, solid, becoming fibrous when old, whitish, 5-10 cm. long, 1.5-3 cm. thick; annulus small.
TYPE LOCALITY: DeFuniak Springs, Florida.
HABITAT: In sandy soil among grass in fields.
DISTRIBUTION: Known only from the type locality. A number of specimens, preserved at Albany as the types, were collected by Dr. G. Clyde Fisher on March 29, 1910.
Reference:
1https://www.mykoweb.com/...

DNA Results and Discussion (posted on 11-Feb-2021):
> A super-clean and sharp nrDNA sequence of 727 bps was derived from a single forward read by Dr. Kudzma from this collection and posted here. It consists of the last 20 bps of nrSSU, followed by the full-length ITS sequence of 669 bps and then by the first 38 base pairs of nrLSU. There are no ambiguities, it’s a single haplotype.
> A BLASTn of the full-length ITS sequence returned several accessions labeled mostly as ‘Agaricus floridanus’ or ‘cf. floridanus’ as top hits, with 99.4-100% similarity:

results.notes:
Agaricus sect. Arvenses

1. CAP
A. SIZE: width up to 12cm at widest point.
B. SHAPE: 1. Convex at first, becoming flat
C. COLOUR: Light chestnut brown, dark at the centre of the cap
D. (1) DRYNESS: Dry and dull
(2) TEXTURE: 55 Scales appressed, Squamose
E. CAP MARGIN: 73 Even when young, becoming 79 split when mature
F. CONTEXT (FLESH)
1. COLOUR: White, no colour change
2. THICKNESS: 2cm thick at margin
3. TEXTURE: Soft, fairly flimsy
G. ODOR & TASTE: Smell fresh and slightly farinaceous, not unpleasant.
Taste mild and agreeable

2. GILLS
A. ATTACHMENT OF GILLS: 101 Free
B. BREADTH: 111 Narrow
C. THICKNESS: 114 Average
D. SPACING: 117 Crowded
E. COLOUR: 1. Very light cream/pink when young
2. Pink-grey turning chocolate brown
F. EDGES: 123 Even

3. STEM
A. LOCATION OF STEM: 141 Central
B. SIZE: Up to 14cm in length from base to junction, up to 2cm across
C. SHAPES: 150 Flexuous, No visible bulb or volva
D. COLOUR & CHANGES: Cream, chestnut brown appressed squamules below the veil remnant
E. SURFACE: Smooth
F. TEXTURE: Pliable, a little fibrous
G. INTERIOR: Solid

4. PARTIAL (INNER) VEIL & REMAINS
A. COLOUR: White
B. TEXTURE: Membranous, cogwheel pattern with brown squamules
C. FATE: Becoming loose and skirt-like
D. RING (ANNULUS): 203 Pendant

5. UNIVERSAL (OUTER) VEIL & REMAINS
A. DESCRIPTION: Membranous, loose and skirt-like remnant
B. VOLVA: Absent

6. MYCELIUM, RHIZOMORPHS, ETC
Whitish mycelium visible at lowest part of stem

7. HABIT
1. Single; and
2. Scattered

HABITAT
6. Terrestrial, in shaded tracts of indigenous afro-temprate forest
Eastern slopes of Table Mountain, Cape Town, South Africa
Late autumn / early to mid winter

PLANT ASSOCIATION
Only found at a few sites in the dense leaf litter of Wild Almond (Brabejum stellatifolium), a native tree of unique botanical importance.
